entry.title: CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned With Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study
entry.summary: Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? In this article, Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container and shares a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on the page.

entry.title: Preparing For Interaction To Next Paint, A New Web Core Vital
entry.summary: Starting in March 2024, Interaction to Next Paint will formally replace First Input Delay as a Core Web Vital metric. Learn how the two metrics differ, why we needed a new way to measure interaction responsiveness, and how you can start optimizing the performance of your site now for a seamless transition to the latest Core Web Vital metric.

entry.title: Five-Second Testing: Taking A Closer Look At First Impressions (Case Study)
entry.summary: Five-second testing is a popular method of usability research used in the industry, yet in essence, its core belief boils down to virtually a superstition. entry.title: How Marketing Changed OOP In JavaScript

entry.title: Recovering Deleted Files From Your Git Working Tree
entry.summary: Git is designed to assure us that we can track a project’s files at different points in time. But it doesn’t assure us that those files are always safe along the way. For those of you who have dealt with the sinking feeling that you’ve irrevocably deleted and lost files, Sanmi has a couple of approaches that, in the right situations, may help bring them back.

entry.title: A Few Ways CSS Is Easier To Write In 2023
entry.summary: We’re living in somewhat of a CSS renaissance with new features, techniques, experiments, and ideas coming at us to an extent we haven’t seen since “CSS3”. It’s easy to feel overwhelmed when your profession seems to be advancing at breakneck speed, but Geoff Graham considers the ways “modern” CSS in 2023 has actually made CSS “easier” to write.

entry.title: An Introduction To Full Stack Composability
entry.summary: A well-designed composable system should not only consider the technical aspects but also take into account the nature of the content it handles. To help us with that, we can use a Headless Content Management system such as Storyblok.

entry.title: CSS Responsive Multi-Line Ribbon Shapes (Part 2)
entry.summary: In Part 1 of the series, Temani Afif demonstrated how creating ribbon patterns in CSS has evolved with the availability of new CSS features. In this second installment of this brief two-part series, we look at two additional ribbon variations that introduce techniques for masking a repeated background gradient in CSS.

entry.title: Creating And Maintaining A Voice Of Customer Program
entry.summary: Product teams benefit from knowing their users’ needs and how they respond to product updates as they build out the roadmap of a product. This article covers Voice of Customer programs and is aimed at those who work on a product team as well as executives who are looking for how to better inform your products using insight from users.

entry.title: An Efficient Design-to-Code Handoff Process Using Uno Platform For Figma
entry.summary: Effective collaboration between designers and developers is vital to creating good user experiences. However, bridging the handoff between design and development with the many tools and workflows available today has its pitfalls. Matthew Mattei introduces you to the Uno Platform, which offers a robust set of productivity boosters.
